item.title: SatoshiLabs Partners with Tech Bureau Bringing Trezor to Japan
item.description:
SatoshiLabs Partners with Tech Bureau Bringing Trezor to Japan

Fintech company Also read: Russian Prime Minister: DAO's an 'Interesting Challenge' for Lawmakers Tech Bureau, located in Osaka, Japan, announced that its subsidiary, bitcoin exchange Zaif, has partnered with SatoshiLabs to help distribute the Trezor Wallet across the Japanese region. Since Spring 2016, Japanese Bitcoin enthusiasm has significantly increased, according to Tech Bureau.

item.title: Is CoinDesk the major publication with regard to Bitcoin and Blockchain?
item.description:
Is CoinDesk the major publication with regard to Bitcoin and Blockchain?

It leads to an interesting conversation: Obama: Hello Judge/Professor Smith, how are you today? Smith: Fine, thank you. What can I do for you, Mr. President? Obama: As you heard, I'm looking to fill a vacancy on the Supreme Court. I'll be honest with you, the Republicans have already said that they won't bring this to a vote.

item.title: Australian bitcoin auction nets $22m
item.description:
Australian bitcoin auction nets $22m

Ernst and Young transactions partner Adam Nikitins said multiple bidders claimed 24,518 units of the digital currency during the auction, which was only the second-ever globally, between June 20-21. The auction was held last week and E&Y announced the result on Tuesday.

item.title: What does Warren Buffet thinks of bitcoin and blockchain?
item.description:
What does Warren Buffet thinks of bitcoin and blockchain?

My friend and I were caught fishing in the Rhodesia National Botanical Garden. We had no idea what we were doing was wrong until a couple of workers saw us, started shouting, grabbed us by the wrists and then hauled us off to the officer in charge.

item.title: What kind of infrastructure can blockchain run on?
item.description:
What kind of infrastructure can blockchain run on?

Answer: Blockchain is a distributed ledger, so it resides on the internet. All nodes participating in the specified blockchain network, have a copy. So there is not special infrastructure needed to run on. This is important for the security of the blockchain, otherwise the infrastructure owner ca...

item.title: What exactly is a bitcoin?
item.description:
What exactly is a bitcoin?

A extremely complex software code. ****** *WHERE DO THEY COME FROM Bitcoins were designed by an unknown person, or persons, known as Satoshi Nakamoto in 2009. They're hidden in an encrypted computer program, from which they're mined by computers.

item.title: EB137 - Siân Jones: Regulatory Update - The Brexit, The EU And The DAO
item.description:
EB137 - Siân Jones: Regulatory Update - The Brexit, The EU And The DAO

With recent news surrounding The DOA and the Brexit vote causing a stir in the blockchain world and beyond, it seems like a regulatory update is due. So we called up our favorite regulatory affairs specialist Siân Jones to enlighten us on some of the recent developments in Bitcoin and blockchain regulation.

item.title: AdvCash User Loses Nearly $5k in Bitcoin Due To Card Cloning
item.description:
AdvCash User Loses Nearly $5k in Bitcoin Due To Card Cloning

Bitcoin enthusiasts will have heard of the company Advcash before. This online platform lets users order virtual and physical debit cards, and balances can be topped up with Bitcoin, among other payment methods. As it turns out, one user has noticed strange account activity, as his account was emptied.

item.title: HashOcean Responds, Cites a Hack, Ready to Resume Usual Payout
item.description:
HashOcean Responds, Cites a Hack, Ready to Resume Usual Payout

After "Is It Down Right Now" reported non-activity on the website of HashOcean for more than five days, major Bitcoin miner whose unresponsiveness has triggered disappointment at cloud mining efforts with suggestions that its investors have been scammed has finally made a public show.

item.title: The DAO: What Dreams May Come
item.description:
The DAO: What Dreams May Come

It hasn't been a while since the recursive call and leakage of three million ETH from the DAO, but the events continue making their turns. The community's reaction towards Ethereum Foundation's actions wasn't very unform. The issue of possible hard fork or soft fork questioned the very foundations of decentralization.
